Situation1: Their partner had a mildly stressful day at work and mentions it casually.
Situation2: The passenger’s train leaves soon and the station is across town
Story: I was just about to start my shift when my partner called, their voice softer than usual. “Work was a bit much today,” they said, not asking for anything, but I could hear the fatigue behind their words. I wanted to be there, to listen, to offer comfort and remind them they weren’t alone. But as I hung up, a passenger slid into the back seat, glancing anxiously at their watch. “My train leaves in twenty minutes. Can you get me to the station?” they asked, urgency in their tone. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in—my partner needed me to be present, to care, while my passenger needed me to focus, to drive fast but safe, to get them across town on time. My hands tightened on the steering wheel, my mind torn between the person I love and the job I must do. I could feel the expectations pulling me in opposite directions, and for a moment, I just sat there, heart pounding, unsure which way to turn.
